importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The timeframe indicates that the flooding events unfolded over a recent period, suggesting a sudden and intense weather-related disaster that overwhelmed infrastructure and emergency services.

keyTakeAways: At least 64 people have died in Mexico due to flooding caused by heavy rains in five states.
The National Civil Protection Coordination (CNPC) chief, Laura Velazquez Alzua, reported 65 people still missing.
Veracruz recorded 29 deaths, followed by Hidalgo with 21, Puebla with 13, and Queretaro with one.
43 people are missing in Hidalgo, 18 in Veracruz, and 4 in Puebla.
Thousands of military troops from the Mexican Army, Air Force, and National Guard have been deployed to assist in rescue and relief operations.
More than 80% of electricity supply has been restored across the five states, with 263,000 users previously without power.
The flooding was attributed to remnants of Hurricane Priscilla and Tropical Rainstorm Raymond, which triggered rapid river rises and landslides.
The heaviest rainfall occurred in Cerro Azul (Veracruz) and Cuetzalan del Progreso (Puebla), with 280mm and 286mm of rain respectively.
Thousands of homes have been affected, with some near rivers described as 'practically disappeared'.
President Claudia Sheinbaum stated there were no prior meteorological warnings indicating such extreme rainfall.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Mexico's death toll from recent flooding has risen to 64, with 65 people still missing, following extreme rainfall in five states caused by the remnants of Hurricanes Priscilla and Raymond. The heaviest rains fell in Veracruz’s Cerro Azul and Puebla’s Cuetzalan del Progreso, with 280mm and 286mm of rain respectively. Veracruz (29 deaths), Hidalgo (21 deaths), and Puebla (13 deaths) were the most affected. Thousands of military personnel from the Army, Air Force, and National Guard have been deployed to deliver food, water, and aid, while nearly 400 repair workers have restored over 80% of electricity across affected states. Over 100,000 homes were impacted, with some near rivers severely damaged or destroyed. President Claudia Sheinbaum and CNPC chief Laura Velazquez Alzua emphasized the lack of prior warning signs, raising concerns about Mexico’s early warning systems and disaster preparedness.
title: Mexico flooding death toll rises to 64, with dozens still missing
